questions.question:
A company produces two types of electrical components, Type A and Type B.

(a) The ratio of production cost of Type A to Type B is 5 : 3. The selling price of Type A is 20% more than its production cost, and the selling price of Type B is 25% more than its production cost. If the total selling price of one unit of each type is $162, find the production cost of Type A.

(b) The company estimates that 3.75 × 10⁴ units of Type A and 2.8 × 10⁴ units of Type B are sold annually. Calculate the total annual revenue from both types, giving your answer in standard form.

(c) Due to inflation, production costs increase by 8% the following year. The company decides to keep the same selling prices. Calculate the percentage decrease in profit per unit of Type A compared to the original profit.
questions.answer:
(a) Let production cost of Type A = 5x, Type B = 3x.
Selling price of A = 1.2 × 5x = 6x
Selling price of B = 1.25 × 3x = 3.75x
Total selling price = 6x + 3.75x = 9.75x = 162
x = 162 ÷ 9.75 = 16.615... ≈ 16.6154
Production cost of A = 5 × 16.6154 = $83.08 (to 2 d.p.)

(b) Revenue from A = 83.08 × 37500 = 3,115,500
Revenue from B = (3 × 16.6154) × 1.25 × 28000 = (49.8462) × 28000 = 1,395,693.6
Total revenue = 3,115,500 + 1,395,693.6 = 4,511,193.6
In standard form: 4.5111936 × 10⁶ ≈ 4.51 × 10⁶ (3 s.f.)

(c) Original profit per unit of A = 6x − 5x = x = 16.6154
New production cost of A = 83.08 × 1.08 = 89.7264
New profit = 99.696 − 89.7264 = 9.9696 (selling price remains 6x = 99.696)
Decrease in profit = 16.6154 − 9.9696 = 6.6458
Percentage decrease = (6.6458 ÷ 16.6154) × 100% ≈ 40.0% (1 d.p.)

mark_scheme.point: Sets up correct ratio expressions for costs and selling prices
Forms correct equation 9.75x = 162 and solves for x
Correctly finds production cost of Type A as $83.08
Correctly calculates revenue from Type A (3,115,500)
Correctly calculates revenue from Type B (1,395,693.6)
Adds revenues and presents in standard form correctly (4.51 × 10⁶)
Calculates original profit per unit of A correctly (16.6154)
Calculates new production cost after 8% increase (89.7264)
Finds new profit (9.9696) and decrease amount (6.6458)
Calculates percentage decrease correctly (40.0%)

common_errors: Incorrect ratio setup (e.g., using selling price ratio instead of cost)
Misinterpreting percentage increase (adding instead of multiplying by 1.08)
Forgetting to convert final revenue to standard form
Using rounded values too early causing cumulative errors
Confusing profit percentage decrease with cost percentage increase

questions.question:
The points A(–3, 2), B(5, 6), and C(9, –2) are vertices of triangle ABC.
(a) Find the equation of the perpendicular bisector of AB. Give your answer in the form y = mx + c.
(b) Show that the point D(1, 4) lies on the perpendicular bisector of AB.
(c) Given that D is the midpoint of AC, find the coordinates of point C.
(d) Calculate the area of triangle ABC.
questions.subtopic: Straight line graphs, Distance and midpoint, Area of triangle
questions.answer:
(a) Midpoint of AB = ((–3+5)/2, (2+6)/2) = (1, 4). Gradient of AB = (6–2)/(5–(–3)) = 4/8 = 1/2. Perpendicular gradient = –2. Equation: y – 4 = –2(x – 1) → y = –2x + 6.
(b) Substitute x=1 into y = –2(1) + 6 = 4. So D(1, 4) lies on the line.
(c) Let C = (x, y). Midpoint of AC = ((–3+x)/2, (2+y)/2) = (1, 4). Solve: (–3+x)/2 = 1 → x = 5; (2+y)/2 = 4 → y = 6. So C(5, 6).
(d) Using coordinates A(–3, 2), B(5, 6), C(5, 6): Note B and C are same point, so triangle is degenerate with area 0. Alternatively, using formula: ½|(–3)(6–6) + 5(6–2) + 5(2–6)| = ½|0 + 16 – 20| = ½|–4| = 2. Correction: C should be (9, –2) as given. Area = ½|(–3)(6–(–2)) + 5(–2–2) + 9(2–6)| = ½|(–3)(8) + 5(–4) + 9(–4)| = ½|–24 – 20 – 36| = ½|–80| = 40 square units.

mark_scheme.point: Finds midpoint of AB correctly: (1, 4)
Finds gradient of AB correctly: 1/2
Finds perpendicular gradient: –2
Forms correct equation of perpendicular bisector: y = –2x + 6
Substitutes x=1 into equation and shows y=4, confirming D lies on line
Sets up midpoint equations for AC: (–3+x)/2 = 1 and (2+y)/2 = 4
Solves to find coordinates of C: (5, 6)
Uses area formula ½|x₁(y₂–y₃) + x₂(y₃–y₁) + x₃(y₁–y₂)| with correct substitution
Correct calculation leading to area = 40
Consistent correct units: square units

common_errors: Using wrong gradient formula (Δx/Δy instead of Δy/Δx)
Not changing sign for perpendicular gradient

Forgetting absolute value in area calculation
Arithmetic errors in area computation

questions.question:
A solid is made by joining a hemisphere of radius 6 cm to a cylinder of the same radius. The total surface area of the solid is 324π cm².

Calculate the height of the cylinder.
questions.subtopic: Surface area and volume of composite solids
questions.answer:
Let height of cylinder = h cm.
Curved surface area of hemisphere = 2πr² = 2π(6)² = 72π cm².
Curved surface area of cylinder = 2πrh = 2π(6)h = 12πh cm².
Area of circular base of cylinder (not exposed) = πr² = π(6)² = 36π cm².
Total surface area = curved surface area of hemisphere + curved surface area of cylinder + area of circular top of cylinder (same as base area) = 72π + 12πh + 36π = (108 + 12h)π cm².
Given total surface area = 324π cm².
So, 108 + 12h = 324
12h = 216
h = 18 cm.

mark_scheme.point: Correct expression for curved surface area of hemisphere: 2π(6)² = 72π
Correct expression for curved surface area of cylinder: 2π(6)h = 12πh
Identifies that only one circular face (top of cylinder) is included in total surface area, adds π(6)² = 36π
Forms correct equation: 72π + 12πh + 36π = 324π or equivalent simplified form
Solves equation correctly to find h = 18

common_errors: Forgetting that the circular base of the cylinder is internal/not part of external surface area
Using total surface area formula for sphere instead of curved surface area for hemisphere
Not simplifying π in the equation correctly

questions.question:
The diagram shows a composite shape made by joining a right circular cone and a hemisphere. The cone has a vertical height of 12 cm and a base radius of 5 cm. The hemisphere has the same radius as the base of the cone. The shape is placed with the hemisphere at the bottom.

(a) Calculate the total surface area of the composite shape, giving your answer in terms of π.
(b) The shape is filled with water. Calculate the volume of water it can hold, giving your answer correct to 3 significant figures.
(c) A similar composite shape is made with all dimensions doubled. Find the ratio of the surface area of the original shape to the new shape.
questions.subtopic: Volume and surface area of composite solids, similarity
questions.answer:
(a) Surface area = curved surface of cone + curved surface of hemisphere (exclude base areas as they are joined).
Curved surface of cone = πrl, where l = √(12² + 5²) = √(144 + 25) = √169 = 13 cm.
So, curved surface of cone = π × 5 × 13 = 65π cm².
Curved surface of hemisphere = 2πr² = 2π × 5² = 50π cm².
Total surface area = 65π + 50π = 115π cm².

(b) Volume = volume of cone + volume of hemisphere.
Volume of cone = (1/3)πr²h = (1/3)π × 5² × 12 = (1/3)π × 25 × 12 = 100π cm³.
Volume of hemisphere = (2/3)πr³ = (2/3)π × 5³ = (2/3)π × 125 = (250/3)π cm³.
Total volume = 100π + (250/3)π = (300π/3 + 250π/3) = (550π/3) cm³.
Numerically: (550 × 3.14159)/3 ≈ 575.96 cm³ ≈ 576 cm³ (3 s.f.).

(c) For similar shapes with all dimensions doubled, linear scale factor = 2.
Surface area scale factor = 2² = 4.
Ratio of surface area (original : new) = 1 : 4.

mark_scheme.point: Correct slant height calculation for cone (l = 13 cm)
Correct curved surface area of cone (65π cm²)
Correct curved surface area of hemisphere (50π cm²)
Correct total surface area (115π cm²)
Correct volume of cone (100π cm³)
Correct volume of hemisphere (250π/3 cm³)
Correct total volume in π form (550π/3 cm³)
Correct numerical volume to 3 s.f. (576 cm³)
Correct identification of linear scale factor (2)
Correct ratio of surface areas (1:4)

common_errors: Adding base area of cone or hemisphere to total surface area
Using wrong formula for curved surface of cone (e.g., πr²)

Incorrectly applying similarity to surface area (using linear instead of square factor)

Dividing by incorrect total (e.g., 5 instead of 20)

questions.question:
The table shows the number of goals scored by a football team in 20 matches.

| Goals scored | 0 | 1 | 2 | 3 | 4 |
| Frequency   | 4 | 6 | 5 | 3 | 2 |

(a) Write down the modal number of goals scored.
(b) Find the median number of goals scored.
(c) Calculate the mean number of goals scored.
questions.answer:
(a) Mode = 1 goal
(b) Median = 1.5 goals
(c) Mean = 1.6 goals

mark_scheme.point: (a) Correctly identifies mode as 1 (highest frequency 6)
(b) Lists all 20 values in order or identifies 10th and 11th values (1 and 2), calculates median as (1+2)/2 = 1.5
(c) Divides total by 20: 32 ÷ 20 = 1.6

common_errors: Confusing mode with highest value instead of highest frequency
Forgetting to average two middle values for median with even dataset
Miscalculating total in mean by multiplying wrong pairs

questions.question:
The cumulative frequency curve shows the distribution of marks scored by 80 students in a Mathematics test.

(a) Use the curve to estimate the median mark.
(b) The pass mark is set at 40. Estimate the number of students who passed the test.
(c) The top 20% of students receive a distinction. Estimate the minimum mark required for a distinction.
questions.answer:
(a) Median = 80/2 = 40th student → From curve, median ≈ 52 marks
(b) At mark = 40, cumulative frequency ≈ 28 students → Passed = 80 - 28 = 52 students
(c) Top 20% = 16 students → 80 - 16 = 64th student → From curve, minimum mark ≈ 68 marks

mark_scheme.point: Correct method for median (80/2 = 40) and reading from curve (51-53)
Correct reading at mark=40 (27-29) and subtraction (80 - reading) for passes
Correct calculation of top 20% (16 students) and reading 64th student from curve (67-69)

common_errors: Using 40 marks instead of 40th student for median
Forgetting to subtract from 80 for number of passes
Calculating 20% of marks instead of 20% of students

questions.question:
The table shows the number of hours spent studying per week by 40 students.

| Hours | 0–4 | 5–9 | 10–14 | 15–19 | 20–24 |
|-------|-----|-----|-------|-------|-------|
| Frequency | 5 | 8 | 12 | 10 | 5 |

(a) Calculate an estimate of the mean number of hours studied.
(b) Write down the modal class.
(c) A student is chosen at random from the group. Find the probability that the student studied for at least 15 hours per week.
questions.answer:
(a) Midpoints: 2, 7, 12, 17, 22
Sum of (midpoint × frequency) = (2×5)+(7×8)+(12×12)+(17×10)+(22×5) = 10+56+144+170+110 = 490
Mean = 490 ÷ 40 = 12.25 hours
(b) Modal class: 10–14 hours
(c) Number of students studying ≥15 hours = 10 + 5 = 15
Probability = 15/40 = 3/8 or 0.375

mark_scheme.point: Correct midpoints (2, 7, 12, 17, 22)
Correct sum of (midpoint × frequency) = 490
Correct mean calculation: 490 ÷ 40 = 12.25
Correct modal class: 10–14
Correct number of students with ≥15 hours: 15
Correct probability: 15/40 = 3/8 or 0.375

common_errors: Using class limits instead of midpoints for mean
Confusing modal class with class with highest midpoint
Incorrect total when calculating probability

questions.question:
The cumulative frequency curve below shows the distribution of marks (out of 100) for 200 students in a Mathematics examination.

[Assume a typical cumulative frequency curve is provided here with points: (0,0), (20,10), (40,50), (60,120), (80,180), (100,200)]

(a) Use the curve to estimate the median mark. [1]
(b) The pass mark is set at 45. Estimate the number of students who passed the examination. [2]
(c) The top 10% of students receive a distinction. Estimate the minimum mark required for a distinction. [2]
(d) The same group of students took an English examination. The interquartile range (IQR) of the English marks is 25, and the IQR of the Mathematics marks is estimated from the curve. State, with a reason, which subject has marks that are more spread out. [1]
questions.answer:
(a) Median = 50 (read from curve at cumulative frequency = 100)
(b) Number who passed = 200 - cumulative frequency at mark 45 ≈ 200 - 65 = 135 students
(c) Top 10% = top 20 students. Minimum distinction mark = mark at cumulative frequency 180 ≈ 78
(d) Mathematics IQR ≈ 62 - 38 = 24. Since 24 < 25, English marks are more spread out because it has a larger IQR.

mark_scheme.point: (a) Correct median read from curve (allow 49-51)
(b) Correct reading of cf at 45 (≈65) and correct subtraction from 200
(c) Correct identification of top 20 students and reading mark at cf=180 (allow 77-79)
(d) Correct IQR for Maths (23-25) and correct comparison with reason

common_errors: Reading cumulative frequency values incorrectly from the graph
Confusing IQR with range or standard deviation
Not subtracting from total for 'passed' calculation

questions.question:
A survey recorded the time, t minutes, taken by 120 students to complete a mathematics problem. The results are summarised in the cumulative frequency table.

| Time (t minutes) | Cumulative Frequency |
|------------------|----------------------|
| 0 < t ≤ 5        | 8                    |
| 0 < t ≤ 10       | 28                   |
| 0 < t ≤ 15       | 64                   |
| 0 < t ≤ 20       | 96                   |
| 0 < t ≤ 25       | 120                  |

(a) On the grid, draw a cumulative frequency diagram to represent this information.

(b) Use your diagram to estimate:
(i) the median time,
(ii) the interquartile range.

(c) The frequency table for the same data is partially completed below.

| Time (t minutes) | Frequency |
|------------------|-----------|
| 0 < t ≤ 5        | 8         |
| 5 < t ≤ 10       |           |
| 10 < t ≤ 15      |           |
| 15 < t ≤ 20      |           |
| 20 < t ≤ 25      |           |

(i) Complete the frequency table.
(ii) Calculate an estimate of the mean time.

(d) A student is chosen at random from the 120 students. Given that the student took more than 15 minutes, find the probability that the student took more than 20 minutes.
questions.subtopic: Histograms and cumulative frequency, Statistical measures, Probability
questions.answer:
(a) Cumulative frequency diagram plotted with points at (5,8), (10,28), (15,64), (20,96), (25,120) joined with smooth curve or straight lines.
(b)(i) Median = 120/2 = 60th value → From diagram, median ≈ 14.5 minutes (accept 14-15).
(b)(ii) Lower quartile = 30th value ≈ 9.5 minutes, Upper quartile = 90th value ≈ 18.5 minutes → IQR = 18.5 - 9.5 = 9 minutes.
(c)(i) Frequencies: 8, 20, 36, 32, 24.
(c)(ii) Mean estimate = (2.5×8 + 7.5×20 + 12.5×36 + 17.5×32 + 22.5×24) / 120 = (20 + 150 + 450 + 560 + 540) / 120 = 1720 / 120 = 14.33 minutes.
(d) P(>20 | >15) = (24) / (32+24) = 24/56 = 3/7 ≈ 0.429.

mark_scheme.point: (a) Correct points plotted at (5,8), (10,28), (15,64), (20,96), (25,120) and joined with smooth curve/straight lines
(b)(i) Median identified as 60th value and correctly read from their diagram (accept 14-15 minutes)
(b)(ii) Lower quartile (30th) and upper quartile (90th) correctly read, IQR calculated correctly
(c)(i) All frequencies correctly calculated: 8, 20, 36, 32, 24
(c)(ii) Correct midpoints used (2.5,7.5,12.5,17.5,22.5) and mean correctly calculated as 14.33
(d) Correct conditional probability: 24/(32+24) = 3/7

common_errors: Using cumulative frequency as frequency in mean calculation
Incorrect reading from cumulative frequency diagram (e.g., using horizontal instead of vertical reading)
Forgetting to subtract cumulative frequencies to find frequencies
Using wrong midpoints for class intervals
Calculating P(>20 and >15) instead of conditional probability
